title: FRQ Score
stimulusHtml:
Always begin with the regular scoring guide. Try an alternate scoring guide only if necessary. (See I.D below.)

I. Regular Scoring Guide

A. Award 1 point for each segment correct in both pitch and rhythm.

· A “segment” is any half measure of the original melody (i.e. any set of three contiguous eighth-note beats), even if occurring over a bar line or beginning on a metrically weak pulse.

· To receive credit, a segment must not overlap with any other segment receiving credit.

· Do not subdivide a note to identify a segment.

· To receive credit, a segment may be metrically shifted from its original position.

· Give no credit for the final note if notation of pitches continues thereafter.

· The following notations will not receive credit: enharmonic equivalents; octave transpositions; dots before the notehead; accidentals after the notehead.

B. If at least one segment is correct in pitch and rhythm, award 1 additional point to the total. For example, a response that is correct in all aspects receives a score of 8 + 1 = 9. Exception: Do not award a 9 unless all measures have the correct number of beats. Award an 8 (i.e., do not award the additional point) to an otherwise perfect response that does not use bar lines correctly.

C. Record any score of 4 or higher and disregard the alternate scoring guides.

D. If after applying A–C the score is less than 4, try an alternate scoring guide.

E. If you try both regular and alternate scoring guides, award the higher of the scores if there is a difference.

F. For ease of scoring, the Alternate Scoring Guides have been accounted for in the point-value options presented. However, scores from the regular scoring guide may not be combined with those from an alternate scoring guide and vice versa.

II. Alternate Scoring Guides (Do not award the additional point to the total.)

A. Award ½ point per segment of correct pitches. (Maximum of 4 points)

OR

B. Award ¼ point per segment of correct rhythm. (Maximum of 2 point)

C. Rounding fractional scores:

· Total scores of ½ and 1½ round up to the closest integer. A total score of 2½ and 3½ round down to the closest integer.

· Quarter points should be rounded to the closest integer.
descriptions:
None of the segments are correct in either pitch or rhythm. [Regular Scoring]

OR

One segment is correct in rhythm. [Alternate Scoring B]

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. One to two segments are correct in pitch [Alternate Scoring A].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Two to five segments are correct in rhythm [Alternate Scoring B].

One segment is correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Three to five segments are correct in pitch [Alternate Scoring A].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Six to eight segments are correct in rhythm [Alternate Scoring B].

Two segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Six or seven segments are correct in pitch [Alternate Scoring A].

Three segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

No segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm. Eight segments are correct in pitch [Alternate Scoring A].
Four segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
Five segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
Six segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

Seven segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].

OR

All eight segments are correct in pitch and rhythm, but bar lines are used incorrectly (not all measures have the correct number of beats) [Regular Scoring].
Eight segments are correct in both pitch and rhythm [Regular Scoring].
